extendedIngredients.name: carrots

title: Corned Beef with Cabbage
summary: Need a caveman, gluten free, dairy free, and primal main course? Corned Beef with Cabbage could be an awesome recipe to try. One portion of this dish contains roughly 36g of protein, 34g of fat, and a total of 520 calories. For $2.92 per serving, this recipe covers 34% of your daily requirements of vitamins and minerals. This recipe serves 8. 1 person were impressed by this recipe. A mixture of cabbage, salt and pepper, corned brisket of beef, and a handful of other ingredients are all it takes to make this recipe so scrumptious. To use up the cabbage you could follow this main course with the Cabbage That Tastes Like Dessert! as a dessert. Taking all factors into account, this recipe earns a spoonacular score of 77%, which is solid. Best Corned Beef 'n' Cabbage, Corned Beef and Cabbage, and Corned Beef and Cabbage are very similar to this recipe.
instructions: Preparation                                                        Put the brisket into a saucepan with the carrots, onions, mustard and the herbs. Cover with cold water, and bring gently to a boil. Simmer, covered, for 2 hours. Discard the outer leaves of the cabbage, cut in quarters and add to the pot. Cook for a further 1 to 2 hours or until the meat and vegetables are soft and tender.                                                                Serve the corned beef in slices, surrounded by the vegetables and cooking liquid. Serve with lots of floury potatoes and freshly made mustard.                                                                            Reprinted with permission from Irish Traditional Cooking by Darina Allen, (C) 1995 (reprinted 2005)

steps.step: Put the brisket into a saucepan with the carrots, onions, mustard and the herbs. Cover with cold water, and bring gently to a boil. Simmer, covered, for 2 hours. Discard the outer leaves of the cabbage, cut in quarters and add to the pot. Cook for a further 1 to 2 hours or until the meat and vegetables are soft and tender.
Serve the corned beef in slices, surrounded by the vegetables and cooking liquid.
Serve with lots of floury potatoes and freshly made mustard.
Reprinted with permission from Irish Traditional Cooking by Darina Allen, (C) 1995 (reprinted 2005)
